title: Work Log
content:
Work Log During my internship at First Cloud Journey, I completed the 12-week program from 15/09/2025 to 07/12/2025. During this time, I learned and practiced with various AWS services, from basic to advanced, and ultimately successfully deployed the CarBuyer project—an e-commerce website for selling cars on the AWS Cloud.
Internship Weeks Overview: Week 1: Getting started with AWS - Account Creation, AWS Budgets, IAM
Week 2: Learning Amazon VPC, EC2, IAM Roles, Cloud9 and S3
Week 3: Learning Amazon RDS, Lightsail, Containers and Auto Scaling
Week 4: Learning CloudWatch, Route 53, AWS CLI and DynamoDB
Week 5: Learning ElastiCache, AWS Networking, CloudFront and Lambda@Edge
Week 6: Learning Amazon WorkSpaces, Directory Services, WordPress HA, Lambda and IAM Tags
Week 7: Writing the Proposal for the CarBuyer project - Architecture Design and Cost Estimation
Week 8: Implementing VPC, IAM, DynamoDB and data migration - Starting the Workshop documentation
Week 9: Implementing S3, CloudFront, Lambda Email Service and Deploying to EC2
Week 10: Testing, bug fixing and continuing to refine the Workshop
Week 11: Reviewing, editing and completing the Workshop documentation
Week 12: Submitting the Workshop and Internship Report

title: Create S3 Bucket
content:
Access S3 Console Select Create bucket Configure bucket: Bucket name: carbuyer-fcj-bucket AWS Region: ap-southeast-1 Block Public Access settings for this bucket: Uncheck “Block all public access” and confirm Bucket Versioning: Select Enable (to support future backups)
Default encryption: Select SSE-S3
Bucket Key: Select Enable
Click Create bucket
Download image files from GitHub here
Select the bucket just created
Select upload from machine and upload the 2 folders below: Database/ SlideShow/ Click Upload
Configure Bucket Policy: Select Permissions tab → Bucket policy → Edit
Paste policy (replace carbuyer-fcj-bucket with your bucket name):
{ "Version": "2012-10-17", "Statement": [ { "Sid": "PublicReadGetObject", "Effect": "Allow", "Principal": "*", "Action": "s3:GetObject", "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::carbuyer-fcj-bucket/*" } ] } Click Save changes

title: Create Security Groups
content:
Create Security Groups In this step, we will create Security Groups to control traffic for 2 EC2 instances.
1. Create Security Group for Customer Service Access EC2 Console → Security Groups Select Create security group Basic Configuration: Name: carbuyer-customer-sg Description: Security group for customer service EC2 VPC: carbuyer-fcj-vpc Inbound Rules: Type Protocol Port Source Description SSH TCP 22 0.0.0.0/0 SSH access Outbound Rules: All traffic (0.0.0.0/0) - Default Select Create security group 2. Create Security Group for Admin Service Note: Use the IPv4 CIDR of Public Subnet AZ 1a noted from step 4.2.1 instead of 10.0.1.0/24.
Select Create security group Basic Configuration: Name: carbuyer-admin-sg Description: Security group for admin service EC2 VPC: carbuyer-fcj-vpc Inbound Rules: Type Protocol Port Source Description SSH TCP 22 10.0.1.0/24 SSH access from Customer EC2 Outbound Rules: All traffic (0.0.0.0/0) - Allow internet access via NAT Gateway Select Create security group Verify Results After completion, you will have the Security Groups:
✅ carbuyer-customer-sg - Customer service in Public Subnet ✅ carbuyer-admin-sg - Admin service in Private Subnet Next, we will create an EC2 instance for Customer Service.

title: Create VPC and Network
content:
Create VPC and Network In this step, we will create a VPC with 4 subnets to deploy EC2 instances.
Create VPC with Wizard Access AWS Console → VPC Select Create VPC Configure VPC settings:
Resources to create: VPC and more Name tag auto-generation: carbuyer-fcj IPv4 CIDR block: 10.0.0.0/16 IPv6 CIDR block: No IPv6 CIDR block Tenancy: Default Number of Availability Zones: 2 Number of public subnets: 2 Number of private subnets: 2 NAT gateways: None VPC endpoints: S3 Gateway DNS options: Enable DNS hostnames and Enable DNS resolution Select Create VPC
After successful creation, select View VPC to see details The VPC wizard will automatically create Internet Gateway, S3 Gateway Endpoint, Route Tables and associate subnets. NAT Gateway will be created manually in step 4.6.3.
Create DynamoDB Endpoint Since VPC wizard only creates S3 Gateway endpoint, we need to create an additional DynamoDB endpoint:
Select Endpoints → Create endpoint Configure:
Name: carbuyer-dynamodb-endpoint Service category: AWS services Service name: com.amazonaws.ap-southeast-1.dynamodb (Type: Gateway) VPC: carbuyer-fcj-vpc Route tables: Select 3 route tables (skip main route table) Select Create endpoint
Record IPv4 CIDR of Public Subnet After successfully creating VPC, note the IPv4 CIDR of Public Subnet AZ 1a:
In VPC Console, select Subnets
Find and note the IPv4 CIDR of subnet:
Subnet name: carbuyer-fcj-subnet-public1-ap-southeast-1a IPv4 CIDR: 10.0.x.x/20 (example: 10.0.0.0/20) Important: Record the exact IPv4 CIDR of this Public Subnet AZ 1a. You will need it to configure Security Group for Admin Service in step 4.6.1.
Next, we will create an IAM Role for EC2 instances.

title: Introduction
content:
Introduction Introduction to Multi-Tier Architecture Multi-Tier Architecture is an application design pattern that separates components into multiple independent tiers. Each tier has distinct responsibilities and communicates with others through well-defined interfaces. This architecture provides benefits such as easy scalability and maintenance, and separation of concerns between tiers. Workshop Overview In this workshop, we will deploy a complete e-commerce website on AWS.
“Customer Service” runs in the public subnet to serve customers accessing from the internet. This service handles functions like viewing car lists, product details, and scheduling test drives. “Admin/Employee Service” runs in the private subnet for internal management. This service is accessible only through Application Load Balancer with path-based routing, handling administrative functions like product management, orders, users, and other items. “Lambda Email Service” is a serverless function that handles sending notification emails to customers when booking test drives or when employees need password resets.

title: Setup IAM Role & Lambda Function
content:
Setup IAM Role & Lambda Function In this section, we will create an IAM Role and Lambda function to handle email sending.
1. Create IAM Role for Lambda on Console Access IAM Console → Roles → Create role:
2. Select trusted entity Select:
Trusted entity type: AWS service Use case: Lambda 3. Attach permissions Find and select policy: AWSLambdaBasicExecutionRole
4. Name the role Role name: carbuyer-lambda-email-role Description: Role for Lambda email service Click Create role
5. Create Lambda function on Console Access Lambda Console → Create a function:
Choose function creation option:
Select Author from scratch Basic information:
Function name: carbuyer-email-service Runtime: Node.js 22.x Architecture: x86_64 Permissions:
Click Change default execution role Select Use an existing role Existing role: carbuyer-lambda-email-role Click Create function
6. Download and upload deployment package Download zip file from GitHub:
Download lambda-email-service.zip In Code tab → Upload from → .zip file:
Select lambda-email-service.zip file just downloaded Click Save 7. Configure Environment Variables In Configuration tab → Environment variables → Edit:
You can use Gmail SMTP or Amazon SES. In this workshop, we will use Gmail SMTP
Add environment variables:
EMAIL_HOST: smtp.gmail.com EMAIL_PORT: 465 EMAIL_USER: your-email@gmail.com (replace with real email) EMAIL_PASS: your-16-char-app-password (Your App Password) Click Save
8. Configure General settings In Configuration tab → General configuration → Edit:
Timeout: 30 seconds Memory: 256 MB Click Save
You have completed setup of IAM Role and Lambda function! Next, move to 4.5.2 - Test Lambda Function.

title: Project Proposal
content:
Deploying a Multi-Tier E-commerce Website for Car Sales on AWS 1. Project Summary CarBuyer is an e-commerce website specializing in car sales, built entirely on the AWS Cloud with a Multi-Tier Architecture. The website provides an online shopping experience for customers and an internal management system for employees and administrators.
Customers can easily search and view details of car models, book a test drive, and receive automatic confirmation emails immediately after registration. Employees are equipped with comprehensive management tools for products (cars and accessories), appointments, along with the ability to update website content such as news and promotional banners. Administrators have the highest level of authority to manage information and accounts for all employees in the system.
The system is designed with a Multi-Tier Architecture on AWS, leveraging managed services to ensure flexible scalability, high security, and cost optimization:
Amazon EC2 — Runs 2 independent Node.js web services: Customer Service (public subnet) and Admin/Employee Service (private subnet). Amazon VPC — Network isolation with 2 public subnets and 2 private subnets across 2 Availability Zones. Amazon DynamoDB — A serverless NoSQL database with 12 tables, auto-scaling on demand. Amazon S3 + CloudFront — Stores product images and delivers them quickly through a global CDN. AWS Lambda + API Gateway — Handles sending email notifications (booking confirmation, password reset) in a serverless model. Application Load Balancer — Intelligently distributes traffic with path-based routing and health checks. 2. Problem and Solution Current Problem The original CarBuyer website was developed with MongoDB and stored data files and images locally, leading to the following issues:
Difficulty in scaling and backing up the database. No CDN for fast image distribution. Lack of an automated email notification system. Significant effort required for infrastructure and database management. Proposed Solution To address these issues, CarBuyer is being migrated to the AWS Cloud with a Multi-Tier Architecture, making maximum use of Managed Services to reduce operational load and increase performance:
DynamoDB replaces MongoDB — Serverless database, auto-scaling. S3 + CloudFront — Stores and distributes images via CDN, reducing latency by 60-70%. Lambda + API Gateway — Sends automated emails (booking confirmation, password reset). VPC — Network isolation with public/private subnets. Application Load Balancer — Distributes traffic with path-based routing. EC2 — Runs Node.js/Express.js with PM2 process manager. Benefits & Return on Investment Reduced Operational Costs — Saves 35-40% compared to traditional VPS thanks to managed services. 80% Reduction in Operational Time — No need to manage servers, databases, or backups. Improved Performance — CloudFront CDN reduces latency by up to 60-70%. High Availability — 24/7 system with Multi-AZ deployment. Automatic Scaling — DynamoDB auto-scaling, Lambda serverless. Automated Emails — Lambda sends booking confirmation and password reset emails. Estimated Monthly Cost (excluding Free Tier): ≈ $85.54 USD Annual Cost: ≈ $1,026 USD
3. System Architecture The system is designed based on the Multi-Tier Architecture model with 3 independent tiers, making it easy to manage, maintain, and scale:
Application Tier Node.js/Express.js: Server-Side Rendering (SSR) handles business logic and renders dynamic HTML on the server. Customer Service (Public Subnet): Web service for customers, accessible from the internet. Admin/Employee Service (Private Subnet): Internal management web service, protected by the private subnet. Application Load Balancer: Distributes traffic between the 2 services with path-based routing. PM2 Process Manager: Manages and monitors Node.js processes. JWT + Express-session: Authentication and session management. Data Tier Amazon DynamoDB: 12 NoSQL tables for data storage (User, Car, Brand, Color, Style, FuelType, Accessory, AccessoryType, News, Review, Slider, Appointment). Amazon S3: Stores product images, news, and sliders. Amazon CloudFront: CDN for fast image distribution. Integration Tier AWS Lambda: Serverless function for handling email sending (booking confirmation, password reset). Amazon API Gateway: REST API endpoints with API Key authentication. AWS Services Used Category Service Compute & Networking EC2 (2 × t3.micro instances), VPC (2 public + 2 private subnets), Internet Gateway, NAT Gateway, Application Load Balancer Database & Storage DynamoDB (12 tables), S3 (object storage), CloudFront (CDN) Serverless & Integration Lambda (email service), API Gateway (REST API) Security & Access IAM (roles & policies), Security Groups, VPC Gateway Endpoints (S3, DynamoDB) 4. Technical Implementation Implementation Phases The CarBuyer migration project to AWS goes through 4 main phases:
Architecture Research and Design: Research AWS services (VPC, EC2, DynamoDB, S3, Lambda, ALB) and design a Multi-Tier architecture suitable for security and scalability requirements. Draw architecture diagrams and identify necessary components.
Cost Calculation and Feasibility Check: Use the AWS Pricing Calculator to estimate the costs of services (EC2, ALB, NAT Gateway, DynamoDB, S3, CloudFront, Lambda) to ensure it fits the budget and provides a good return on investment. Evaluate the feasibility of the solution.
Architecture Adjustment for Cost/Solution Optimization: Refine the architecture (e.g., using VPC Gateway Endpoints for S3/DynamoDB to reduce NAT Gateway costs, choosing DynamoDB on-demand instead of provisioned) to balance performance and cost.
Development, Testing, Deployment: Build the VPC networking, migrate the database from MongoDB to DynamoDB, develop the Lambda email service, deploy Node.js applications to EC2 with PM2, configure ALB and CloudFront, then perform end-to-end testing and go live.
Technical Requirements Application Layer: Node.js/Express.js with SSR, PM2 process manager managing 2 services (Customer and Admin/Employee). Uses JWT + express-session for authentication. Frontend HTML/CSS/JavaScript rendered dynamically from the server.
AWS Infrastructure: Multi-Tier architecture with VPC (2 public + 2 private subnets across 2 AZs), EC2 t3.micro instances, Application Load Balancer (path-based routing), NAT Gateway, Internet Gateway, Security Groups, IAM roles/policies.
Data & Storage: DynamoDB (12 NoSQL tables: User, Car, Brand, Color, Style, FuelType, Accessory, AccessoryType, News, Review, Slider, Appointment), S3 (for image storage), CloudFront CDN (for content delivery), VPC Gateway Endpoints (S3, DynamoDB).
Serverless Integration: Lambda function (Nodemailer + Gmail SMTP) handles email notifications (booking confirmation, password reset), API Gateway with REST endpoints and API Key authentication.
Development Tools: AWS SDK (@aws-sdk/client-dynamodb, @aws-sdk/client-s3, @aws-sdk/lib-dynamodb), AWS CLI, Git, SSH, Nodemailer.
5. Roadmap & Milestones Month Outcome Month 1 Complete learning AWS fundamentals, design architecture. Finalize VPC networking, IAM setup, DynamoDB tables, S3 + CloudFront Month 2 Finalize SSR application (Node.js), Lambda email service, API Gateway, EC2 deployment, ALB configuration Month 3 Testing, optimization, workshop documentation End of Month 3 Deploy to Production 6. Cost Estimation AWS Service Costs (estimated for 1,000 - 1,500 active users/month, excluding Free Tier) Service Description Monthly Cost (USD) EC2 2 × t3.micro instances (730 hours) $20.44 Application Load Balancer 730 hours + LCU charges $21.32 NAT Gateway 730 hours + data processing (2GB) $43.10 DynamoDB 12 tables, on-demand mode, 1GB storage $0.29 S3 Standard 10GB storage + 25K requests $0.28 CloudFront CDN distribution, 5GB origin transfer $0.10 Lambda Email service (1K requests/month) $0.01 API Gateway REST API (1K requests/month) $0.00 ➡ Total Monthly Cost: ≈ $85.54 USD ➡ Annual Cost: ≈ $1,026 USD
7. Risk Assessment Risk Matrix Risk Impact Probability Cost overruns Medium Low Security vulnerabilities High Medium Performance issues Medium Low Email delivery failures Low Medium Mitigation Solutions:
Set up CloudWatch billing alerts and AWS Budgets. Apply the principle of least privilege for IAM roles (grant only the minimum necessary permissions). Use restrictive Security Group rules and private subnets. Implement retry logic and error logging in Lambda. CloudFront CDN and DynamoDB auto-scaling for performance. 8. Expected Outcomes Technical Outcomes A complete e-commerce platform for car sales with a Multi-Tier architecture. A secure and scalable system with VPC, Security Groups, ALB, CloudFront. Automated email notifications with Lambda and API Gateway. 80% reduction in operational time and 35-40% cost savings compared to traditional VPS. Long-term Value Demonstrates practical skills in Serverless and DevOps. Can be scaled to thousands of users without architectural changes. Serves as a standard AWS architecture template that can be reused for future projects.

title: Create CloudFront Distribution
content:
Access CloudFront Console
Click Create distribution
At Distribution options section: Distribution name: fcj-cloudfront-carbuyer Distribution type: Single website or app Configure Origin: Origin type: Select Amazon S3 Origin domain: Select carbuyer-fcj-bucket.s3.ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com Origin path: Leave empty Configure Security: Web Application Firewall (WAF): Select Do not enable security protections Review information and select Create distribution After deployment, copy Distribution domain name (format d1234abcd.cloudfront.net) Test CloudFront URL: https://yourcloudfront.cloudfront.net/Database/danhgia/1760497475406-65792375.jpg

title: Create EC2 Instances
content:
Create EC2 Instances In this section, we will create 2 EC2 instances for Customer Service and Admin/Employee Service.
Steps 1. Create EC2 Instance for Customer Service Access EC2 Console at EC2 Dashboard Select Launch an instance Name and tags: Name: carbuyer-customer-service Application and OS Images (Amazon Machine Image): Select Amazon Linux 2023 AMI Architecture: Select 64-Bit (x86) Instance type: Select t2.micro (Free tier eligible) 1 vCPU, 1 GiB Memory Key pair (login): Key pair name: carbuyer-keypair (or create new if not exists) Key pair type: RSA Private key file format: .pem Network settings: Select Edit to configure:
Network (VPC): carbuyer-fcj-vpc Subnet: Select Public Subnet AZ 1a (10.0.0.0/20) Auto-assign public IP: Enable Firewall (security groups): Select existing security group → carbuyer-customer-sg Configure storage: Keep default: 8 GiB gp3 (Free tier eligible) Advanced details: IAM instance profile: carbuyer-ec2-role Select Launch instance 2. Create EC2 Instance for Admin/Employee Service Select Launch an instance again Use the same configuration as Customer Service but change: Name and tags: Name: carbuyer-admin-service Network settings (Edit): Network (VPC): carbuyer-fcj-vpc Subnet: Select Private Subnet AZ 1b (10.0.3.0/24) Auto-assign public IP: Disable Firewall (security groups): Select existing security group → carbuyer-admin-sg Keep other configurations unchanged (AMI, instance type, key pair, IAM role)
Select Launch instance
3. Verify instances In EC2 Console, select Instances from the left menu Confirm both instances are in Running state:
carbuyer-customer-service - Public subnet, has Public IP carbuyer-admin-service - Private subnet, only has Private IP Verify information:
Instance State: Running Status Check: 2/2 checks passed Security Groups: Correct security group assigned IAM Role: carbuyer-ec2-role Verify Results After completion, you will have:
✅ EC2 Customer Service instance in public subnet ✅ EC2 Admin Service instance in private subnet ✅ Both instances have IAM role carbuyer-ec2-role ✅ Security groups configured correctly ✅ Instances ready to install applications Next, we will setup the environment for the instances.

title: Create IAM Role
content:
Create IAM Role for EC2 In this section, we will create an IAM Role for EC2 instances to securely access AWS services.
Create IAM Role Access IAM → Roles → Create role Select trusted entity type: Trusted entity type: AWS service Use case: EC2 In the add permissions section, assign these policies under Permissions policies: AmazonDynamoDBFullAccess AmazonS3FullAccess CloudFrontFullAccess Name the role: Role name: carbuyer-ec2-role Description: Role for EC2 to access AWS services Select Create role Verify the created role Next, we will create IAM User and Access Keys for the application.

title: Prerequisites
content:
Prerequisites In this section, we will prepare the networking infrastructure and access permissions needed to deploy the CarBuyer application to AWS.
Requirements Before starting the workshop, you need:
AWS Account - You can use Free Tier for most services Basic Knowledge - Understanding of Node.js, networking, and basic AWS concepts Web Browser - To access AWS Console Overview We will set up the following foundational resources:
Amazon VPC with 4 subnets (2 public, 2 private) across 2 Availability Zones to ensure high availability Internet Gateway to allow traffic from internet into public subnets Route Tables to route traffic between subnets VPC Endpoints (S3 Gateway and DynamoDB Gateway) to access AWS services without going through the internet IAM Role for EC2 instances to access DynamoDB and S3 IAM User and Access Keys for Node.js application to use AWS SDK NAT Gateway will be created later in step 4.6.3 when needed for private subnet.
Content Create VPC and Network Create IAM Role for EC2 Create IAM User and Access Keys

title: Test Lambda Function
content:
Test Lambda Function In this section, we will test the Lambda function with 2 types of emails: Reset Password and Booking Confirmation.
1. Create Test Event for Reset Password In the Test tab: Test event action:
Select Create new event Invocation type:
Select Synchronous Event name:
Enter: test-reset-password Event sharing settings:
Select Private Template:
Select Hello World Event JSON: Delete the default content and paste:
{ "type": "RESET_PASSWORD", "data": { "email": "test@example.com", "resetUrl": "https://yourapp.com/reset-password?token=abc123" } } Click Save
2. Run Reset Password Test Click Test to run the test event. Check the results in Execution results:
3. Create Test Event for Booking Confirmation Create a new test event in the Test tab:
Test event action:
Select Create new event Event name:
Enter: test-booking-confirmation Event sharing settings:
Select Private Template:
Select Hello World Event JSON: Delete the default content and paste:
{ "type": "BOOKING_CONFIRMATION", "data": { "email": "customer@example.com", "hoTenKH": "Nguyễn Văn A", "id": "BK001", "soDT": "0901234567", "ngayTao": "2024-01-15", "time": "14:30" } } Click Save
4. Run Booking Confirmation Test Select the test-booking-confirmation test event and click Test:
You have completed testing the Lambda function! Next, proceed to 4.5.3 - Setup API Gateway.

title: Week 3 Worklog
content: Week 3 Objectives: Master knowledge of Amazon RDS and database management. Get familiar with Amazon Lightsail and application deployment. Understand Containers and how to deploy on Lightsail Container. Learn about Auto Scaling and Load Balancing. Tasks to be carried out this week: Day Task Start Date Completion Date Reference 2 - Learn about Amazon RDS + RDS Database Engines + Multi-AZ Deployments + Read Replicas + Backup and Restore - Practice: + Create VPC and Security Groups + Create RDS Database Instance + Deploy application connected to RDS + Perform Backup and Restore 29/09/2025 29/09/2025 https://000005.awsstudygroup.com/ 3 - Learn about Amazon Lightsail + Lightsail Instances + Networking Configuration + Snapshots + Monitoring and Alarms - Practice: + Deploy WordPress Instance + Deploy PrestaShop E-Commerce + Deploy Akaunting Instance + Create Snapshots and Scale Instance 30/09/2025 30/09/2025 https://000045.awsstudygroup.com/ 4 - Learn about Lightsail Container + Container Service + Docker Images + Deploy from Public Registry - Practice: + Create Container Service + Deploy Public Image + Build and Push Custom Image + Deploy Container 01/10/2025 01/10/2025 https://000046.awsstudygroup.com/ 5 - Learn about EC2 Auto Scaling + Launch Templates + Auto Scaling Groups + Scaling Policies + Load Balancer Integration - Practice: + Create Launch Template + Setup Application Load Balancer + Create Auto Scaling Group + Test Manual, Scheduled, Dynamic Scaling 02/10/2025 02/10/2025 https://000006.awsstudygroup.com/ Week 3 Achievements: Successfully deployed RDS database. Deployed various applications on Lightsail (WordPress, PrestaShop). Understood how to work with Containers and deploy on Lightsail Container Service. Set up Auto Scaling Group with Load Balancer for automatic application scaling. Practiced backup, restore, and monitoring of resources. Challenges: Initially, I was not familiar with configuring Security Groups for RDS, so it took quite a bit of time to troubleshoot. Need to learn more about Docker to better understand Container deployment. Plan for Next Week: Master knowledge of Amazon CloudWatch and monitoring. Understand Route 53 and Hybrid DNS.

title: Create DynamoDB Database
content:
Create DynamoDB Database In this section, we will create the necessary DynamoDB tables for the CarBuyer application and import sample data.
Introduction to Amazon DynamoDB Amazon DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database service that provides fast and predictable performance with seamless scalability.
Key Advantages:
High Performance - Low latency at single-digit milliseconds for both read and write operations Serverless - No need to manage servers, automatically scales based on demand Flexible Billing - On-demand pricing mode charges only for what you use, no minimum capacity High Availability - Automatically replicates data across multiple Availability Zones Good Integration - Native integration with other AWS services like Lambda, API Gateway, S3 Database Structure The CarBuyer application uses 12 DynamoDB tables to store data:
Table Description Partition Key User User information (admin, employee, customer) id (String) XeOto Car information (model, price, specs) id (String) ThuongHieu Car and accessory brands id (String) MauXe Car colors id (String) KieuDang Car types (Sedan, SUV, Hatchback…) id (String) NguyenLieuXe Fuel types (Petrol, Diesel, Hybrid, Electric) id (String) PhuKien Car accessory information id (String) LoaiPhuKien Accessory types (interior, exterior…) id (String) TinTuc News and articles id (String) DanhGia Customer reviews id (String) Slider Homepage slider images id (String) DatLichKH Customer test drive scheduling id (String) Content Create DynamoDB Tables Import Sample Data

title: Create IAM User and Access Keys
content:
Create IAM User and Access Keys We need to create an IAM User with Access Keys so both Node.js applications (Customer and Admin) can access DynamoDB and S3.
Create IAM User In IAM Console, select Users → Create user Configure user: User name: carbuyer-app-user Provide user access to the AWS Management Console: DO NOT select (this user is only for the application) Attach permissions policies: AmazonDynamoDBFullAccess AmazonS3FullAccess CloudFrontFullAccess Confirm information and select Create user Create Access Keys Click on the carbuyer-app-user user just created Select Security credentials tab Scroll down to Access keys section, click Create access key Select use case: Command Line Interface (CLI) (Optional) Add description tag: carbuyer-app-keys Click Create access key
Important: Copy and save both pieces of information:
Access key ID Secret access key: Click Download .csv file to save credentials
Click Done
Caution: This is the only time you can see the Secret Access Key. If lost, you must create a new access key. Do not commit credentials to Git or share publicly.
Next, we will create DynamoDB tables.

title: Setup API Gateway
content:
Setup API Gateway In this section, we will create a REST API and deploy it to call the Lambda function from outside.
1. Create API Gateway REST API Access API Gateway Console → Create API:
Select REST API → Build API name: carbuyer-email-api Description: API for Lambda email service Endpoint Type: Regional IP address type: IPv4 Click Create API
2. Create Method In the newly created API:
Create Method on root resource:
Select resource / Click Create method Method details:
Method type: POST Integration type: Lambda function Lambda proxy integration: ✅ Lambda function: arn:aws:lambda:ap-southeast-1:442228338540:function:carbuyer-email-service Integration timeout: 29000 Method request settings:
Authorization: None Request validator: None API key required: ✅ Click Create method and verify the result
3. Deploy API After successfully creating the method, find the Deploy API button in the top right corner:
Click Deploy API:
Deployment stage: *New stage* Stage name: prod Stage description: Production stage Click Deploy
Save the Invoke URL for use in EC2
Save the Invoke URL: Copy this URL for use in section 4.6 Deploy EC2
You have completed setting up API Gateway! Next, proceed to 4.5.4 - Setup API Security.

title: Setup EC2 Environment
content:
Setup EC2 Environment In this section, we will connect and configure the environment for the EC2 instances.
1. Create NAT Gateway for Admin Service In VPC Console, select NAT Gateways Select Create NAT Gateway Configure NAT Gateway:
Name: carbuyer-nat-gateway Subnet: Select Public Subnet AZ 1b (carbuyer-fcj-subnet-public2-ap-southeast-1b) Connectivity type: Public Elastic IP allocation ID: Select Allocate Elastic IP Select Create NAT Gateway
Update Route Table for Private Subnet AZ 1b: In VPC Console, select Route Tables Find route table for Private Subnet AZ 1b (carbuyer-fcj-rtb-private2-ap-southeast-1b) Select route table → Routes tab → Edit routes Add route: Destination: 0.0.0.0/0 Target: NAT Gateway just created Save changes 2. Connect to Customer Service Instance In EC2 Console, select Instances Select instance carbuyer-customer-service, select Connect Select EC2 Instance Connect tab Select Connect to open terminal in browser 3. Install Node.js and PM2 Install Node.js 22: # Update system sudo yum update -y sudo yum install -y git # Install Node.js 22 curl -fsSL https://rpm.nodesource.com/setup_22.x | sudo bash - sudo yum install -y nodejs # Install PM2 globally sudo npm install -g pm2 Verify installation: node --version npm --version pm2 --version 4. Connect to Admin Service Instance (via Bastion) Copy private key to Customer Service instance: # Create .ssh directory if not exists mkdir -p ~/.ssh chmod 700 ~/.ssh # Create private key file (paste content from carbuyer-keypair.pem) nano ~/.ssh/carbuyer-keypair.pem chmod 400 ~/.ssh/carbuyer-keypair.pem Connect to Admin Service: # Get private IP of admin instance from EC2 console ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=accept-new -i ~/.ssh/carbuyer-keypair.pem ec2-user@ADMIN_PRIVATE_IP Install Node.js and PM2 for Admin Service: # Update system sudo yum update -y sudo yum install -y git # Install Node.js 22 curl -fsSL https://rpm.nodesource.com/setup_22.x | sudo bash - sudo yum install -y nodejs # Install PM2 globally sudo npm install -g pm2 Verify installation: node --version npm --version pm2 --version Next, we will setup Application Load Balancer

title: Week 4 Worklog
content: Week 4 Objectives: Master knowledge of Amazon CloudWatch and monitoring. Understand Route 53 and Hybrid DNS. Become proficient in using AWS CLI. Learn about DynamoDB and NoSQL databases. Tasks to be carried out this week: Day Task Start Date Completion Date Reference 2 - Learn about Amazon CloudWatch + CloudWatch Metrics + CloudWatch Logs + CloudWatch Alarms + CloudWatch Dashboards - Practice: + View and analyze Metrics + Use Logs Insights + Create Metric Filters + Set up Alarms and Dashboards 06/10/2025 06/10/2025 https://000008.awsstudygroup.com/ 3 - Learn about Route 53 and Hybrid DNS + Route 53 Resolver + Inbound Endpoints + Outbound Endpoints + Resolver Rules - Practice: + Deploy on Microsoft AD + Create Outbound and Inbound Endpoints + Configure Resolver Rules 07/10/2025 07/10/2025 https://000010.awsstudygroup.com/ 4 - Learn about AWS CLI + Install and configure AWS CLI + AWS CLI Profiles + Output Formats - Practice: + Manage S3 with CLI + Manage SNS with CLI + Manage IAM with CLI + Manage VPC with CLI + Create EC2 with CLI 08/10/2025 08/10/2025 https://000011.awsstudygroup.com/ https://aws.amazon.com/vi/cli/ 5 - Learn about Amazon DynamoDB + DynamoDB Tables + Primary Keys + Indexes + Query and Scan - Practice: + Create DynamoDB Table + CRUD Operations with Python SDK + Query and Scan data + Load sample data 09/10/2025 09/10/2025 https://000060.awsstudygroup.com/ Week 4 Achievements: Successfully set up CloudWatch monitoring for resources. Understood how to create Alarms and Dashboards for system monitoring. Deployed Hybrid DNS with Route 53 Resolver. Became proficient in using AWS CLI to manage various AWS services. Worked with DynamoDB and understood the differences between NoSQL and SQL. Challenges: Initially, I was not familiar with AWS CLI syntax, so I had to refer to the documentation frequently. Needed time to fully understand the difference between Query and Scan in DynamoDB. Plan for Next Week: Master knowledge of ElastiCache and caching. Gain deeper understanding of AWS Networking. Learn about CloudFront and CDN.

title: Configure S3 and CloudFront
content:
Configure S3 and CloudFront In this section, we will set up a storage and static content distribution system for the CarBuyer application using Amazon S3 and CloudFront CDN.
Introduction to Amazon S3 Amazon S3 (Simple Storage Service) is an object storage service designed to store and retrieve any amount of data from anywhere on the web.
Key Advantages:
High Durability - 99.999999999% (11 nines) durability with automatic replication Scalability - Automatically scales to handle any amount of data Cost-effective - Pay only for actual storage and bandwidth used Security - Supports encryption, bucket policies, and access control lists Integration - Integrates well with CloudFront, Lambda, and other AWS services Introduction to Amazon CloudFront Amazon CloudFront is a Content Delivery Network (CDN) service that distributes content to users with low latency and high transfer speeds.
Key Advantages:
Global Network - Over 400 edge locations worldwide Low Latency - Caches content near end users Security - Integrated with AWS Shield for DDoS protection Cost Optimization - Reduces bandwidth costs from S3 origin HTTPS Support - Free SSL/TLS certificates with AWS Certificate Manager Storage Architecture In this workshop, we will:
Create S3 bucket to store static assets:
Car product images (in Database/ folder) Homepage slider images (in SlideShow/ folder) Other media files Configure CloudFront distribution to:
Cache and distribute content from S3 origin Reduce latency for users in different regions Optimize bandwidth costs CloudFront will cache content at edge locations, reducing requests to S3 and significantly improving performance.
Content Create S3 Bucket Create CloudFront Distribution

title: Setup API Security
content:
Setup API Security In this section, we will create an API Key and Usage Plan to secure the API Gateway.
1. Create API Key for Security In API Gateway Console → API Keys → Create API Key:
API key details:
Name: carbuyer-email-api-key Description: API key for CarBuyer email service (optional) API key:
Select Auto generate Click Save
Save the API Key for later use
2. Create Usage Plan Click Usage Plans → Create:
Usage plan details:
Name: carbuyer-email-plan Description: Usage plan for CarBuyer email API (optional) Throttling:
Rate: 100 requests per second Burst: 200 requests Quota:
Requests: 10000 Per: month Click Create usage plan
3. Add API Stage to Usage Plan Go back to Usage Plans → click on carbuyer-email-plan:
In Associated stages tab:
Click Add API Stage API: Select carbuyer-email-api Stage: Select prod Click Add to usage plan 4. Add API Key to Usage Plan In Associated API keys tab:
Click Add API Key Select carbuyer-email-api-key Click Add API Key Save the API Key: Copy this API Key for use in section 4.6 Deploy EC2
Now proceed to 4.6 - Deployment to deploy the application to EC2.

title: Setup Application Load Balancer
content:
Setup Application Load Balancer (ALB) In this section, we will configure Application Load Balancer to prepare for deploying applications with cookie-based session persistence.
Why ALB Before Deployment? Session Management: ALB manages sticky sessions for admin/employee Load Balancing: Distributes traffic between instances Health Checks: Automatically checks application status Scalability: Easy to add instances later Steps 1. Create Security Group for ALB Access EC2 Console → Security Groups → Create security group:
Security group name: carbuyer-alb-sg Description: Security group for CarBuyer ALB VPC: Select VPC created in step 4.2.1 Inbound rules:
Type: HTTP, Port: 80, Source: 0.0.0.0/0 Type: HTTPS, Port: 443, Source: 0.0.0.0/0 Outbound rules: (default - All traffic)
2. Update Security Groups for EC2 Customer Service Security Group:
Add rule: Type: Custom TCP, Port: 3000, Source: carbuyer-alb-sg Admin Service Security Group:
Add rule: Type: Custom TCP, Port: 3001, Source: carbuyer-alb-sg 3. Create Target Groups Target Group for Customer Service:
Access Target Groups → Create target group:
Create target group: Target type: Instances Target group name: carbuyer-customer-tg Protocol: HTTP, Port: 3000 VPC: Select VPC created Health check path: / Click Next
Register targets (recommended): Leave empty - Don’t select any instances Click Next Review and create: Verify configuration Click Create target group Target Group for Admin & Employee Service:
Repeat the steps above with:
Target group name: carbuyer-admin-employee-tg Protocol: HTTP, Port: 3001 Health check path: /admin/login or /employee/login 4. Configure Stickiness for Admin & Employee Target Group In Target Group carbuyer-admin-employee-tg:
Actions → Edit target group attributes Stickiness: Enabled Stickiness type: Load balancer generated cookie Stickiness duration: 1 days Select save changes 5. Create Application Load Balancer Access Load Balancers → Create load balancer
Select create Application Load Balancer:
Basic configuration:
Name: carbuyer-alb Scheme: Internet-facing IP address type: IPv4 Network mapping:
VPC: Select VPC created Mappings: Select both public subnets Security groups: Select carbuyer-alb-sg Listeners and routing:
Protocol: HTTP, Port: 80 Default action: Forward to carbuyer-customer-tg Click Create load balancer
6. Configure Listener Rules After ALB is created, go to Listeners tab:
Rule 1 - Admin paths:
Click on listener HTTP:80 Manage rules → Add rule Name and tags:
Name: admin-rule Conditions:
Add condition → Select Path Path pattern: /admin/* Actions:
Routing action: Forward to target groups Target group: Select carbuyer-admin-employee-tg Weight: 1, Percent: 100% Click Next
Set rule priority: Priority: 100 (or any number from 1-50,000) Click Next Review and create: Verify configuration Click Add rule Rule 2 - Employee paths:
Add rule following similar steps: Add rule: Name: employee-rule Condition: Path = /employee/* Action: Forward to carbuyer-admin-employee-tg Set rule priority: Priority: 200 (different from admin rule) Review and create: Click Add rule Additional rules:
Add the following rules using similar steps:
Priority Rule Name Path Pattern Target Group Stickiness 100 admin-rule /admin carbuyer-admin-employee-tg Off 101 admin-rule-2 /admin/* carbuyer-admin-employee-tg Off 200 employee-rule /employee/* carbuyer-admin-employee-tg Off 300 private-rule /private/* carbuyer-admin-employee-tg Off 400 login-rule /login carbuyer-admin-employee-tg Off 500 forgot-psw-rule /forgot* carbuyer-admin-employee-tg Off 600 reset-psw-rule /reset-password* carbuyer-admin-employee-tg Off 7. Get ALB DNS Name In Load Balancers → Select carbuyer-alb:
Copy DNS name: carbuyer-alb-xxxxxxxxx.ap-southeast-1.elb.amazonaws.com Save ALB DNS Name: This DNS name will be used in step 4.6.5 to configure applications
8. Verify ALB Status State: Active Target Groups: Both target groups created Listeners: HTTP:80 with configured rules Verify Results After completion, you will have:
✅ ALB with DNS name ready ✅ Target Groups for Customer (port 3000) and Admin/Employee (port 3001) ✅ Sticky sessions configured for admin/employee ✅ Security Groups updated ✅ Listener rules for path-based routing Next proceed to 4.6.5 - Deploy Applications to deploy applications and add instances to Target Groups.

title: Workshop
content:
Deploy Node.js Application to AWS with Multi-Tier Architecture Overview Welcome to the workshop on Amazon EC2, DynamoDB, S3, CloudFront, and AWS Lambda!
In this workshop, we will learn and deploy a Node.js application to AWS using a multi-tier architecture. We will explore how to set up VPC networking, deploy EC2 instances, configure DynamoDB database, and deploy serverless email service with Lambda. Afterward, we will apply the learned knowledge by deploying a real-world e-commerce application called CarBuyer on these services.
Duration This workshop may take approximately 90-120 minutes to complete.
Content Introduction - Learn about the CarBuyer application (car sales website), overall architecture, and AWS services used in the workshop including EC2, DynamoDB, S3, CloudFront, Lambda.
Prerequisites - Prepare networking infrastructure and access permissions: create VPC with public/private subnets, Internet Gateway, Route Tables, IAM Role for EC2, IAM User and Access Keys for the application.
Create DynamoDB Database - Create 12 DynamoDB tables for entities such as User, Car, Brand, Color, Type, Material, Accessory, AccessoryType, News, Review, Slider, BookingSchedule. Import sample data into the tables.
Configure S3 and CloudFront - Create S3 bucket to store static assets (product images, news, slider). Configure bucket policy for public access. Create CloudFront distribution for content delivery with low latency through global CDN.
Lambda Email Service - Deploy serverless email notification service using AWS Lambda and API Gateway. Configure Lambda function to send confirmation emails for booking schedules and password resets. Create REST API endpoint and configure API Key security.
Deploy Application to EC2 - Create Security Groups, initialize 2 EC2 instances (Customer Service in public subnet and Admin/Employee Service in private subnet). Configure NAT Gateway for private subnet. Setup Application Load Balancer with path-based routing and sticky sessions. Deploy Node.js application with PM2 process manager.
Cleanup Resources - Delete all created AWS resources in the correct order to avoid incurring costs

content:

The focus of the internship was the “CarBuyer” project, where I participated in building and deploying a complete multi-tier e-commerce web application on the AWS platform.
My journey with AWS has been a comprehensive technical development experience, including:

title: Deploy Applications
content:
Deploy Applications In this section, we will deploy the carbuyer-aws application to both EC2 instances and connect with the ALB setup in step 4.6.4.
1. Deploy Customer Service Connect to Customer Service instance (already connected from step 4.6.3)
Clone repository:
cd ~ git clone https://github.com/khaizr0/carbuyer-aws.git cd carbuyer-aws/customer-service Install dependencies: npm install Create .env file for Customer Service: nano .env Paste the following content (replace with actual values):
# Server Configuration PORT=3000 BASE_URL=http://YOUR_ALB_DNS_NAME SESSION_SECRET=carbuyer_session_secret_2024_production # AWS Configuration (DynamoDB + S3) AWS_REGION=ap-southeast-1 AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=your_access_key_from_4.2.3 AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=your_secret_key_from_4.2.3 # S3 + CloudFront S3_BUCKET=carbuyer-fcj-bucket S3_PUBLIC_URL=https://YOUR_CLOUDFRONT_ID.cloudfront.net # JWT Configuration JWT_SECRET=carbuyer_jwt_secret_production_2024 # Lambda Email Service LAMBDA_EMAIL_API_URL=https://YOUR_API_GATEWAY_URL/prod/send-email LAMBDA_EMAIL_API_KEY=your_api_key_from_4.5.4 # Google Maps Configuration GOOGLE_MAPS_EMBED_URL=https://www.google.com/maps/embed?pb=!1m18!1m12!1m3!1d2098.047098103885!2d106.70327503669084!3d10.772062044514472!2m3!1f0!2f0!3f0!3m2!1i1024!2i768!4f13.1!3m3!1m2!1s0x31752f3acf87eaeb%3A0xc969a1975f3be32a!2sBitexco%20Financial%20Tower!5e0!3m2!1svi!2s!4v1760106692113!5m2!1svi!2s Save file: Ctrl + X, Y, Enter
Start application with PM2: pm2 start app.js --name "customer-service" pm2 startup pm2 save 2. Deploy Admin Service Connect to Admin Service instance (already connected from step 4.6.3): # From Customer Service instance ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=accept-new -i ~/.ssh/carbuyer-keypair.pem ec2-user@ADMIN_PRIVATE_IP Clone repository and install: cd ~ git clone https://github.com/khaizr0/carbuyer-aws.git cd carbuyer-aws/employee-and-admin-service npm install Create .env file for Admin Service: nano .env # Server Configuration PORT=3001 BASE_URL=http://YOUR_ALB_DNS_NAME SESSION_SECRET=carbuyer_session_secret_2024_production # AWS Configuration (DynamoDB + S3) AWS_REGION=ap-southeast-1 AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=your_access_key_from_4.2.3 AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=your_secret_key_from_4.2.3 # S3 + CloudFront S3_BUCKET=carbuyer-fcj-bucket S3_PUBLIC_URL=https://YOUR_CLOUDFRONT_ID.cloudfront.net # JWT Configuration JWT_SECRET=carbuyer_jwt_secret_production_2024 # Lambda Email Service LAMBDA_EMAIL_API_URL=https://YOUR_API_GATEWAY_URL/prod/send-email LAMBDA_EMAIL_API_KEY=your_api_key_from_4.5.4 Start Admin Service with PM2: pm2 start app.js --name "admin-service" pm2 startup pm2 save 3. Add Instances to Target Groups Add Customer Service instance: Access Target Groups → Select carbuyer-customer-tg Targets tab → Register targets Select Customer Service instance
Port: 3000
Click Include as pending below → Register pending targets Confirm result after register
Add Admin Service instance: Select carbuyer-admin-employee-tg Targets tab → Register targets Select Admin Service instance Port: 3001 Click Include as pending below → Register pending targets
Confirm result after register
Check Health Status: Wait 2-3 minutes for health checks to run Both targets must be in healthy state Next proceed to 4.6.6 - Test Application to verify the application.

title: Lambda Email Service
content:
Lambda Email Service In this section, we will deploy a serverless email notification service for the CarBuyer application using AWS Lambda and API Gateway.
Introduction to AWS Lambda AWS Lambda is a serverless compute service that allows you to run code without managing servers. Lambda automatically scales and you only pay for actual compute time used.
Key Advantages:
Serverless - No need to manage infrastructure, AWS automatically handles scaling and patching Pay-per-use - Pay only for invocations and compute time, no idle costs Auto-scaling - Automatically scales from a few requests to thousands per second Event-driven - Trigger from multiple sources like API Gateway, S3, DynamoDB Free Tier - 1 million free requests and 400,000 GB-seconds compute time per month Introduction to Amazon API Gateway Amazon API Gateway is a fully managed service to create, publish, maintain, monitor, and secure APIs.
Key Advantages:
RESTful APIs - Supports REST API with HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) Security - API Keys, IAM authorization, Lambda authorizers Throttling - Rate limiting to protect backend services Monitoring - Integrated with CloudWatch for metrics and logs CORS Support - Easy configuration of cross-origin requests Email Service Architecture In this workshop, we will:
Create Lambda function to:
Handle confirmation emails for test drive bookings Send password reset emails Use Gmail SMTP to send emails Create API Gateway REST API to:
Expose Lambda function via HTTP endpoint Configure API Key authentication Deploy API to production stage Integrate with application to:
Customer Service and Admin Service call API to send emails Use API Key to secure requests Lambda function will use Gmail SMTP. You need a Gmail account and create an App Password to use it.
Implementation Steps Setup IAM Role & Lambda Function Test Lambda Function Setup API Gateway Setup API Security Important Information to Save After completing the steps, save 2 important pieces of information for use in section 4.6:
1. API Gateway Invoke URL (from step 4.5.3):
https://YOUR_API_ID.execute-api.ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com/prod 2. API Key (from step 4.5.4):
YOUR_GENERATED_API_KEY Important Note: Both pieces of information will be used in the application’s .env configuration file in section 4.6.

title: Feedback & Contributions
content:
General Evaluation 1. Work Environment The work environment at AWS is professional, results-oriented, and encourages autonomy. I was provided with sufficient resources and a quiet space to focus on complex technical tasks.
2. Mentor / Team Admin Support My mentor acted as a strategic guide rather than giving detailed instructions. He gave me the final goals of the project and encouraged me to do my own research, debug, and find solutions. This approach was challenging at first, but it helped me grow tremendously in my problem-solving mindset. The admin team was also very prompt in assisting with necessary procedures.
3. Job-Major Alignment The work was not only suitable but also a practical extension of the knowledge about computer networks and distributed systems that I had learned. It connected theoretical concepts (like the OSI model, databases) with real-world services and architectures on the cloud.
4. Learning & Skill Development Opportunities This was a great opportunity for me to understand the “big picture” of a cloud-native application. Instead of just focusing on code, I learned how infrastructure components (networking, storage, compute, database) interact with each other to create a complete, secure, and scalable system.
5. Culture & Team Spirit The culture here promotes a sense of “ownership”. Everyone is responsible for their part but is always willing to share knowledge when needed. The technical discussions, though infrequent, were very deep and of high quality.
6. Intern Policies / Benefits The flexible work policy helped me balance my studies and the internship. More importantly, having access to an AWS account and being allowed to build a real project was the biggest benefit, providing me with experience that cannot be found in books.
Other Questions What I was most satisfied with: The moment I successfully debugged a network connection issue between the EC2 instance in the private subnet and the NAT Gateway. At that point, I truly understood how VPC routing, security groups, and network ACLs work together. It was a wonderful “eureka” moment.
Areas for Improvement: Currently, I have no suggestions for improvement; the FCJ admin team is doing a great job.
If you were to recommend it to friends, would you advise them to do an internship here? Why? Definitely. I would tell them: “If you want a deep, hands-on experience building secure and scalable cloud infrastructure from scratch, and not just writing code, then this is the place for you.”
Proposals & Wishes Future Wishes: I wish to continue my journey with FCJ after this internship ends. I feel there is still much more I can learn here, and I will continue to strive for that.
Other Feedback: I sincerely thank the internship program for giving me a solid technical foundation and a realistic view of the cloud industry. The knowledge and experience from the CarBuyer project will surely be something I will be proud to talk about in the future.

title: Deploy Application to EC2
content:
Deploy Application to EC2 In this section, we will deploy the CarBuyer application to Amazon EC2 instances with 2 separate services.
Introduction to Amazon EC2 Amazon EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) provides scalable virtual servers in the cloud, allowing you to run applications with flexible configuration.
Key Advantages:
Flexible - Many instance types with different CPU, memory, storage configurations Scalable - Easy to scale up/down based on demand Cost-effective - Pay only for actual compute capacity used Secure - Security Groups and Network ACLs to control traffic Reliable - Deploy across multiple Availability Zones for high availability Introduction to Application Load Balancer Application Load Balancer (ALB) operates at layer 7 (application layer), distributing incoming traffic to multiple targets like EC2 instances.
Key Advantages:
Path-based Routing - Route requests based on URL path Health Checks - Automatically checks target health and routes only to healthy instances SSL/TLS Termination - Handles HTTPS connections High Availability - Automatically distributes traffic across multiple Availability Zones Integration - Works well with Auto Scaling, CloudWatch, and other AWS services Deployment Architecture In this workshop, we will deploy 2 separate Node.js applications:
Customer Service (Public subnet):
EC2 instance running Node.js application Serves customers: view cars, schedule test drives, buy accessories Accessible from internet via Application Load Balancer Connects to DynamoDB via VPC Gateway Endpoint Admin/Employee Service (Private subnet):
EC2 instance running Node.js application Internal management: CRUD cars, accessories, news, orders, customers Accessible via ALB (for admin) or SSH (for employees) Connects to internet via NAT Gateway to download packages Connects to DynamoDB via VPC Gateway Endpoint Application Load Balancer:
Distributes traffic to both EC2 instances Health checks to ensure availability Path-based routing: / → Customer Service, /admin → Admin Service NAT Gateway:
Allows Admin Service (private subnet) to access internet Required for downloading npm packages and system updates VPC Gateway Endpoints:
DynamoDB endpoint: Access DynamoDB without internet S3 endpoint: Upload/download media files from S3 Content Create Security Groups Create EC2 Instances Configure Network Setup Application Load Balancer Deploy Applications Test Application

title: Cleanup Resources
content:
Cleanup Resources After completing the workshop, you should delete the resources to avoid unexpected costs.
Make sure you have backed up important data before deleting!
Deletion order is important: Resources must be deleted in the correct order to avoid dependency errors.
1. Delete Application Load Balancer Access EC2 Console → Load Balancers Select carbuyer-alb Click Actions → Delete load balancer Confirm by typing: confirm Click Delete ALB must be deleted before Target Groups and EC2 instances.
2. Delete Target Groups In EC2 Console, select Target Groups Delete each target group: carbuyer-customer-tg, carbuyer-admin-employee-tg Select target group → Actions → Delete Confirm 3. Delete EC2 Instances In EC2 Console, select Instances Select both instances: carbuyer-customer-service, carbuyer-admin-service Click Instance state → Terminate instance Confirm deletion Wait for instances to transition to Terminated state before continuing.
4. Delete NAT Gateway Access VPC Console → NAT Gateways Select carbuyer-nat-gateway Click Actions → Delete NAT gateway Confirm by typing: delete Wait 2-3 minutes for NAT Gateway to be completely deleted 5. Delete Elastic IP In VPC Console, select Elastic IPs Select Elastic IP created for NAT Gateway Click Actions → Release Elastic IP address Confirm Unattached Elastic IPs will be charged. Delete immediately after removing NAT Gateway!
6. Delete API Gateway Access API Gateway Console Select API carbuyer-email-api
Click Delete
Confirm by typing: confirm Click Delete 7. Delete Lambda Function Access Lambda Console Select function carbuyer-email-service Click Actions → Delete Confirm by typing: confirm Click Delete 8. Delete CloudFront Distribution Access CloudFront Console Select distribution fcj-cloudfront-carbuyer Click Disable Wait a few minutes for status to change to Disabled Select distribution, click Delete Confirm deletion CloudFront distribution must be Disabled before it can be deleted.
9. Delete S3 Bucket Access S3 Console Select bucket carbuyer-fcj-bucket
Click Empty to delete all objects
Confirm by typing: permanently delete Click Empty Go back, select bucket and click Delete Confirm by typing bucket name: carbuyer-fcj-bucket Click Delete bucket 10. Delete DynamoDB Tables Access DynamoDB Console Select Tables from left menu Select table to delete: DanhGia, DatLichKH, KieuDang, LoaiPhuKien, MauXe, NguyenLieuXe, PhuKien, Slider, ThuongHieu, TinTuc, User, XeOto
Select table, click Delete
Confirm by typing: confirm Verify result after deletion 11. Delete Security Groups Access EC2 Console → Security Groups Delete security groups: carbuyer-customer-sg, carbuyer-admin-sg Select security group → Actions → Delete security groups Confirm Repeat the process to delete carbuyer-alb-sg 12. Delete VPC Endpoints Access VPC Console → Endpoints Select endpoints to delete
Select endpoint → Actions → Delete VPC endpoints
Confirm 13. Delete VPC In VPC Console, select Your VPCs Select carbuyer-fcj-vpc
Click Actions → Delete VPC
Confirm by typing: delete Click Delete Deleting VPC will automatically delete related resources: subnets, route tables, internet gateway.
14. Delete IAM Roles Access IAM Console → Roles Select roles: carbuyer-ec2-role, carbuyer-lambda-email-role
Select Delete
Confirm by typing: delete Click Delete 15. Delete IAM User In IAM Console, select Users Select user carbuyer-app-user Click Delete Select Deactivate access key Confirm and select Delete user 16. Delete Key Pair Access EC2 Console → Key Pairs Select carbuyer-keypair
Click Actions → Delete
Confirm
